answers: path dependence [or path dependent; do not accept or prompt on “path independence”]
work [accept PV work]
temperature [or T; accept isotherms, isothermal surface, or isothermal processes]
parts: Name this property. In the first law of thermodynamics, adding two terms with this property yields one without it.

This inexact differential is expressed as PdV and has a negative sign because it follows the convention of the system acting on the surroundings, not vice versa. The change in internal energy equals this quantity plus heat.

An adiabatic process produces only work and moves between two curves that are constant in this quantity. When this quantity is constant, work is proportional to the natural log of the ratio of final to initial volume.

answers: Gospel of Mark
Desiderius Erasmus [or Desiderius Erasmus Roterodamus; or Erasmus of Rotterdam]
King James Version [or KJV; or King James Bible or KJB; or Authorized King James Version or AKJV]
parts: Name this book whose last twelve verses, or “Longer Ending,” are subject to academic debate about their authenticity. In those verses of this book, the apostles are given the Great Commission to proclaim the gospel to all nations.
Mark’s Longer Ending was found in all Greek manuscripts available to this humanist scholar, who compiled Greek New Testament manuscripts into the Textus Receptus.
The Textus Receptus is the basis for this Bible translation, which was commissioned by its namesake king of England.

answers: The Women of Algiers in Their Apartment [or Femmes d’Alger dans leur appartement]
Eugene Delacroix (“duh-lah-KWAH”) [or Ferdinand Victor Eugene Delacroix]
Pierre-Auguste Renoir
parts: Identify this painting, sketches of which were made during the artist’s 1832 trip abroad with Count Charles-Edgar de Mornay. A figure in this painting holds the end of a hookah.
This artist painted numerous orientalist works like The Women of Algiers and The Massacre at Chios. He is most famous for painting Liberty Leading the People.

This later artist imagined three Parisian women “Dressed in Algerian costumes.” In another of his paintings, Gustave Caillebotte (“kye-BUT”) wears a straw hat as he dines with others at the Maison Fournaise (“may-ZAWN foor-NEZ”) restaurant on the Seine (“sen”).

answers: Shaolin Temple [or Shaolin Monastery]
Red Turban Rebellion [or Hóngjīn Qǐyì; prompt on the fall of the Yuan dynasty or the rise of the Ming dynasty or equivalents]
Shanghai [or Huátíng; or Shēnchéng; or HùVu]
parts: Identify this temple on the slope of Mount Song in Henan (“huh-nahn”) Province where a monk named Bodhidharma helped develop China’s martial arts tradition.

Much of the Shaolin Temple was destroyed in the 14th century during this Chinese rebellion, whose leader claimed to be a reincarnation of Maitreya. Korea under the Goryeo (“kor-yuh”) dynasty was invaded during this rebellion.
The Stupa of the Four Heroic Monks in this city honors Shaolin monks who died at the Battle of Taozhai (“tao-jye”) in 1555. Today, this financial capital of China is the country’s most populous city.

answers: A Doll’s House [or Et dukkehjem]
Henrik Ibsen
closet dramas
parts: Name this play whose controversial original ending was explored in a modern sequel by Lucas Hnath (“nayth”). Nils Krogstad blackmails the central character in this play.
A Doll’s House is by this Norwegian playwright of The Wild Duck.

Ibsen’s Peer Gynt is a play described by this adjective, meaning it was primarily meant to be read instead of performed. Catherine Burroughs’s book on these dramas argues they’re “dominated by a ‘literary’… element conducive to the act of contemplation.”

answers: Wilt Chamberlain [or Wilton Norman Chamberlain]
Robert Nozick
libertarianism
parts: Name this person who receives 25 cents from one million people in that thought experiment. Since everyone consented to distribution D2, the author argues that D2 is just.
This philosopher created that “paying Wilt Chamberlain” thought experiment while advocating a “night watchman state” in his book Anarchy, State, and Utopia.
Nozick pushed a right-wing version of this philosophy in Anarchy, State, and Utopia. Partisans of this viewpoint support drastically reducing intervention by the state.

answers: Regents v. Bakke [or Regents of the Univ. of Cal. v. Bakke; prompt on Regents]
Grutter v. Bollinger [or Barbara Grutter, Petitioner v. Lee Bollinger, et al.]
Richard Nixon [or Richard Milhous Nixon]
parts: Name this 1978 Supreme Court case about race-based admission quotas at a California medical school.

Generals such as John Shalikashvili (“shah-lee-ka-SHVEE-lee”) joined the “military brief” that was influential in deciding this later affirmative action case. This case was decided on the same day as a similar case named for Gratz.

This president promoted affirmative action in federal contracts through the Philadelphia Order. The dog-whistle politics of his “Southern Strategy” helped him secure states like Florida in the 1968 election.

answers: elastic [or elasticity; accept elastic effects]
stress [accept yield stress; accept shear stress]
thixotropy [or thixotropic fluid]
parts: Whipped cream exhibits tastiness, viscous effects, and effects described by this word. Unlike plastic materials, these materials return to their original shape and size after being deformed.
Toothpaste caves under high values of this quantity because it’s a Bingham plastic. Young’s modulus is the ratio of this quantity to strain.

Peanut butter, especially when mixed with jelly, displays this behavior, just like ketchup. In this common behavior, applying shear stress to a colloidal suspension causes it to have a lower viscosity; in other words, shaking ketchup makes it thinner.

answers: Syria [or Syrian Arab Republic] (The contemporary poet is Adunis.)
Seneca the Younger [or Lucius Annaeus Seneca]
Ovid [or Naso; or Publius Ovidius Naso]
parts: Name this country that the aforementioned member of the gens Publilius was named after. This modern country was the birthplace of a contemporary author with the pen name Adunis who wrote Songs of Mihyar.
Publilius Syrus’s fans include this Roman philosopher, who quoted him in two of the Moral Letters to Lucilius. This philosopher also wrote the bloody tragedies Thyestes and Hercules Furens.
The pen name of Syrian poet Adunis (“ah-doh-NEESE”) reflects his “pan-Mediterranean muses,” such as this poet whose tale of Venus and Adonis is included in Adunis’s translation of his Metamorphoses.

answers: staccato
arpeggios [or arpeggi; accept “The Arpeggio”]
ricochet bowing [or jeté; accept saltando, sautillé, or spiccato due to conflation]
parts: Name this style of articulation, usually performed by shortening notes to sound disconnected. This articulation is contrasted with playing legato.
The first of Paganini’s caprices is nicknamed for one of these “broken chords,” in which the notes of a chord are played in series rather than simultaneously.
This bowing creates a series of notes that split the two halves of Paganini’s caprice “La Chasse (“shahss”).” The violinist “throws” the bow onto the strings so that it bounces in this technique.

answers: Ukraine [or the Ukraine]
Five Star Movement [or Five Stars Movement; or Movimento 5 Stelle; or M5S]
Iceland [or Ísland] (The comedian was Jón Gnarr, born Jón Gunnar Kristinsson.)
parts: Volodymyr Zelenskiy, who played a history teacher-turned-president on television, became the real-life president of this country in 2019 and quickly faced some pressure to investigate Hunter Biden.
This Italian political party was co-founded by TV actor Beppe Grillo and asserts that access to the Internet is a fundamental right.

A comedian was elected mayor of this country’s capital after the 2008 financial crisis and spent years battling its restrictive naming committee. This country sentenced Kaupthing Bank executives to prison after the financial crisis.

answers: Ada Lovelace [or Augusta Ada King, Countess of Lovelace; or Ada Byron; accept Ada]
Alan Turing [or Alan Mathison Turing; accept Turing test or Turing machines]
Stephen Wolfram [accept Wolfram Language]
parts: Identify this computer scientist who names a language derived from Pascal and an award given by the Association for Women in Computing.
The various Lovelace tests are extensions on the imitation game named for this man, which has supposedly been passed by various AI. His namesake machines can compute any algorithm.

This later computer scientist defended Lovelace from charges that her contributions to the field have been overhyped. This man’s namesake programming language powers a computing system called Mathematica.

answers: Bulgars [or Bulgarians]
Constantinople [or Byzantium; prompt on Istanbul]
Boris I [or Boris-Mihail; or Boris Michael; or Boris Fyodorovich Godunov]
parts: Name these people who were soundly defeated at the Battle of Kleidion by Basil II, who was nicknamed the “Slayer” of these people.
The Bulgars were a frequent enemy of the Byzantine Empire, though the two fought together from 717 to 718 to repel a Umayyad invasion against this capital city of the Byzantines.

The Bulgars converted to Christianity under a king of this name, who ended his abdication after his son Vladimir reverted to paganism. A Russian ruler of this first name issued the Edict of 1587 formally bonding serfs to the land.

answers: Howards End
E. M. Forster [or Edward Morgan Forster]
Leonard Bast [or Leonard Bast]
parts: Name this 1910 novel that also loosely inspired Zadie Smith’s novel On Beauty. The protagonist of Smith’s novel shares his name with the country house that titles this novel, in which the Schlegel sisters appear.
Lopez makes this author of Howards End and A Passage to India a character named Morgan in The Inheritance.

In The Inheritance, this character from Howards End is partly represented by the social climber Adam McDowell. In the original novel, this character dies of a heart attack after being beaten with a saber by Charles Wilcox.

answers: gloves [or lady’s gloves; or mittens; accept opera gloves]
commedia dell’arte [or Italian comedy; or Comédie-Italienne]
Cologne [or Koln; accept eau de cologne]
parts: Name these objects that Swede Levov produces from his Newark factory in Philip Roth’s novel American Pastoral. The mousquetaire (“moose-kuh-TAIR”) variety of these things were traditionally worn to the opera.
Orris root, a perfume ingredient, was often kept in a container shaped like a figure from this theater tradition, whose stock characters included Pulcinella and Pierrot.
Johann Maria Farina was the first to make a perfume named for the “eau” or “water” of this German city. This city now lends its name to any type of perfume marketed towards men.

answers: dreams [or nightmares; or dream sequence; do not accept or prompt on “daydream”]
Salvador Dalí [or Salvador Domingo Felipe Jacinto Dalí i Domènech, 1st Marquess of Dalí de Púbol]
L’Age d’Or (“lahzh dor”) [or The Golden Age or Age of Gold]
parts: Name this type of event. One of these events reveals the origins of a man’s phobia in Alfred Hitchcock’s Spellbound.
This Surrealist artist designed sharply angled sets for the dream sequence in Spellbound. Luis Buñuel and this man filmed ants crawling out of a man’s hand in Un Chien Andalou.
Dalí and Buñuel also collaborated on this other film, which opens with a short documentary on scorpions.

answers: Ezra Pound [or Ezra Weston Loomis Pound]
Elizabeth Bishop
Marianne Moore [or Marianne Craig Moore] (That poem is “Poetry.”)
parts: Name this American fascist poet of “In a Station of the Metro” who included Chinese characters in The Cantos.
This poet wrote of meeting the incarcerated Pound in her “Visit to St. Elizabeths.” The refrain “The art of losing isn’t hard to master” is found in her poem “One Art.”
Bishop’s memoir Efforts of Affection concerns this mentor of hers, who conjured “imaginary gardens with real toads in them” in a popular poem.

answers: sumptuary laws
samurai
Benin [or Kingdom of Benin; or Republic of Benin]
parts: Identify this Latin-derived term for laws that regulate how people can dress or what types of luxury goods they can buy.

Sumptuary laws in Edo-era Japan helped preserve the prestige of these people over richer chōnin (“CHO-neen”) merchants. These aristocrats were the only ones allowed to wear two swords and followed the bushido code.

Only nobles in this West African kingdom could wear coral around their necks. The British looted this kingdom’s namesake bronzes, and it shares its name with a modern-day country whose most populous city is Cotonou (“ko-to-NOO”).

answers: mutation
Drosophila melanogaster [or D. melanogaster; or common fruit fly; or vinegar fly; prompt on fly]
guanine [prompt on G]
parts: Identify these alterations which include transversions and transitions.
The Heidelberg Screen was carried out on these model organisms, the subject of a genome project at Berkeley. Lilian and Thomas Hunt Morgan performed research on this organism.
A common way to induce point mutations is to use ethyl methanesulfonate to alkylate this nucleobase. The protonated N1 of this compound helps cisplatin preferentially bind to it.

answers: Troy [or Ilium]
Achelous
a fountain [or a spring]
parts: The river god Scamander who flowed near this city was so angered by Achilles choking him with all the men he was killing that he fought him three times, nearly killing Achilles. Achilles would later kill Hector, a prince of this city.

This river god transformed himself into a bull and a serpent to fight Heracles for the hand of Deianira (“DAY-uh-NEE-ruh”). According to some accounts, the horn that this god lost in that battle became the cornucopia.

The river god Alpheus relentlessly pursued Arethusa (“air-uh-THOO-zuh”), who transformed into one of these objects. Shortly after his birth, Pegasus created one of these objects called the Hippocrene.

answers: House of Lords [or House of Peers; or the Right Honourable the Lords Spiritual and Temporal of the United Kingdom of Great Britain and Northern Ireland in Parliament assembled]
The People’s Budget [prompt on the 1909 and 1910 UK budget]
Marquess of Salisbury [or Lord Salisbury; or Viscount Cranborne; or Earl of Salisbury]
parts: Name this upper house in the British Parliament whose power was restricted by the Parliament Act of 1911.
In 1909, the House of Lords rejected a budget of this name that included proposals to “wage implacable warfare against poverty” by Chancellor of the Exchequer David Lloyd George.

In 1945, a holder of this title, Robert Gascoyne-Cecil, agreed to the custom that the House of Lords wouldn’t delay most legislation. An earlier holder of this title thrice served as Conservative Prime Minister in the late 19th century and presided over the Second Boer War.
